clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Marijuana Used on Lung Function in Persons With Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Marijuana Smoking on Pulmonary Function in Patients With COPD

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock: The main hypothesis is that persons that smoke or smoked tobacco and marihuana have worsen lung function as compared with persons that only smoke or smoked tobacco.

detailed_description.textblock: We will follow persons with already diagnosed COPD (chronic bronchitis and/or emphysema). Obtain their smoking history: tobacco and marihuana and review their pulmonary function study results. Then we are planning to compare both groups.

primary_outcome.measure: Obstructive limitation in pulmonary function test
primary_outcome.description: Comparison on the severity of obstruction among both groups

secondary_outcome.measure: Decreased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison on the severity of decreased DLco among groups.
Comparison on the severity of air-trapping by pulmonary function testing among groups.

arm_group.description: COPD patients with history of tobacco and/or marihuana smoking.

study_pop.textblock: COPD patients recruited in pulmonary clinic.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- COPD patients former or current tobacco smokers
- COPD patients former or current tobacco and marihuana smokers
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of COPD without pulmonary function testing
- Refusal to provide smoking or marihuana used history
